title: Body Language in Sixteenth- and Seventeenth-Century European Art
description: Renaissance artists invested considerable time and energy in understanding the physical composition of the human body in order to create powerful body images that told a story or represented social identity. In this seminar we first consider the ways in which Leonardo and Michelangelo studied the human corpse, as well as how anatomical knowledge was simplified and mediated through books on drawing such as DÃ¼rer's Four Books on Human Proportions. We then examine the academic practice of nude drawing; the collection of codified gestures in Bulwer's Chirologia or the Natural Language of the Hand; Charles Le Brun's research on facial expression; and contemporaneous descriptions of narrative painting, which focused on the eloquence of body movement, gesture, and expression. Finally, we consider issues tied to idealization and debasement of the body, and the phenomena of empathy and distaste as reactions provoked in an artwork's beholder by specific renderings of the human figure. We discuss questions of social habitus and gender and reflect on various pictorial approaches to expressing character and mood in front of selected paintings in New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art.
